snippet: Employment prospects for college-educated workers have eroded, so a degree doesn’t necessarily mean a good-paying job anymore.
abstract: Editorial notes unemployment rates are rising and wages stagnating for recent college grads; holds, contrary to popular wisdom, college education itself does not create good jobs at good pay; contends policy makers must confront fact that fastest growing jobs pay low wages and do not require a degree, requiring creation of pathways from low-paid jobs to better paying jobs.
lead_paragraph: Employment prospects for college-educated workers have eroded, so a degree doesn’t necessarily mean a good-paying job anymore.
